description: Tooofffuuuuu and sauce! Seriously the sauce is amazing and no offense their chicken is, um, not good. It's simple and likely not the highest grade. The tofu absorbs the sauce better and their rice is super good too. Did I mention you should get an extra sauce? :)
author: Jason P.

description: The only really clean meal option I know in the FIDI/SOMA area in SF. All "healthy" options out there aren't clean. they usually come with sauces, unwanted carbs and fat, etc. This is your paleo/ clean/ macro-friendly go to.
author: Debora C.

description:
Still solid. Probably one of the best/healthiest lunch options in SOMA.

Once again, I ordered the "Marina" sans egg on top. Damn, this meal certainly satisfies. The dish consists of brown rice, poached/skinless chicken breast, cucumbers , brown rice, and a side of bone broth. Make sure to snag a few sauces (everything from a soy sauce medley to a spicy red sauce) to douse on your poultry.

Word to the wise... Order in advance (online or by phone). If you just show up to the restaurant during lunch hours, prepare for a long wait. Also, prepare for a large portion. I usually have a pretty appetite, but I could only eat half of my "Marina." Fortunately, I enjoyed the rest of it at home for dinner.

This place is a winner!
author: Kevin B.

description: It's good, but not the best Khao mun gai I've ever had. Nong's in Portland is better. The portion size is larger than expected. It's pretty simple: steamed chicken, cooked Thai style, over a ginger and garlic rice. The line was about 15 minutes long when I came. I don't think it's worth queuing up for. Feels very sterile.
author: Billy S.

description:
I had actually been thinking (read: dreaming) about the Marina location of Rooster & Rice recently and wanted to go back. One day while running errands in SoMa, I Yelped a place for lunch and discovered that Rooster & Rice opened up another location nearby! Jackpot!! It was in the middle of the lunch rush, but I think enough people are unaware of the awesomeness that is Rooster & Rice, so it wasn't too much of a wait. 

Of course, I got the Khao Mun Gai "The Original" which is soooo delicious. Love how limited this menu is. They specialize in just a few things, and you can add a few extras on top of whatever you order. Each dish comes with a small bowl of chicken soup. Hot, fresh, and tasty. The chicken and rice comes with a side of garlic and ginger sauce, which is the perfect degree of seasoning. You can also drench everything with the hot sauce available. Gives it a nice kick. 

Rooster & Rice is one of my favorite lunch spots in the city. I'm never in the Marina, so this SoMa location is quite a blessing. There's plenty of seating outside in the plaza. On a sunny San Francisco day, the greenery and fountain are gorgeous. There's also some seating inside -- more than the Marina location -- but I prefer sitting outdoors while enjoying this warm and cozy meal.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Came here for lunch... now don't get me wrong, the food is good! Just got the chicken and the rice (duh) and a poached egg. Chicken was pretty good, flavorful and so was the rice. The egg was meh. The sauce was really good too! The soup is definitely a winner, though the portion is very small... but BOY is it pricey... it's just literally rice and chicken... maybe it's an Asian thing, lol. 2 dollars for an egg?! geebus.. SF, you are killing me!!! This is one of those places where it's definitely a treat vs. an everyday lunch. I spent $15 dollars on it, and it's just chicken, egg and rice? lol. if it was maybe fish and rice, or steak and rice then I think $15 is ok, but eeeek.... You guys know I am more than willing to pay for food when it's worth it..

Service was good though..def want to also try that fried chicken skin.....

I will be back when I am craving and willing to splurge a bit....
author: Judy W.

description:
I ordered the marina with extra chicken for lunch. I also got an egg for $2 and that was very disappointing. It was sloppily done, kind of runny but not really. Everything else was fantastic, reminiscent of hainan chicken and rice. 

The wait for not too long, about 10 minutes in liken and another 10 minutes for food. They also had a Thai sriracha sauce, and a habanero sauce. However I'd say the sauce provided with the lunch box went along much better than the sriracha and habanero. 

The location has a lot of sunshine, is close by to a fountain with plenty of open space where lots of people come to enjoy their meal. It was a pleasant experience with delicious food. Just wish the egg was done better!
author: Alex S.

description: Bland chicken that tastes like nothing with a pound of rice thats $14. Might as well get a chicken burrito bowl from chipotle, half the price. 3x the flavor, cant believe this place is surviving. Soend your money elsewhere
author: Mike A.

description:
I was hit with a great smell upon entering this place.  The concept and food is pretty simple.  The Marina is my staple dish.  Good portion of tender chicken breast sliced up over brown rice.  I love the little broth they give you.

I don't think $13 bucks for lunch is crazy at all.  I hear from random people how this place is kind of expensive.  I don't get it.  If the food tastes fresh and healthy, then expect to weigh that into the price.

This place is kind of far for me but a worthy lunch spot for meal rotation.
author: John M.

description:
Okay, it's more like a 3.5. It was too good to be a 3, but I needed to like it a little bit more to bump my rating to a 4. 

The chicken by itself tastes absolutely bland, and yes, it's all in the sauce, but I found the sauce similar to the sauce you dip XLBs or dumplings in, just with a whole lot of ginger... ALOT. 

I've had similar types of Chinese, Hainan Chicken, and generally those chicken have an inherent chicken-y umami flavor that doesn't rely so much on a soy based sauce. I did love the broth though, it was light and refreshing tasting. I like putting the chicken into the broth and eating it that way. 

Seasonal vegetables, if you get them, are guaranteed steamed broccoli (crunch is still retained!), and sliced cucumbers, nothing out of the ordinary. 

To me, this meal didn't strike me as Thai. My Thai friend tells me the traditional way is cooking the rice in the chicken broth, but my brown rice was plain. It's worth a try, but I wouldn't come back again. This was also an EXPENSIVE lunch. But you will be full!

UPDATE: I came back to try a second time. I got the paleo this time, with chicken thighs. GET THE THIGHS. It is alot more tender, and alot more tasty! I think the thighs make all the difference. So much protein, and a whole ton of broccoli. Broth is standard and good. I tried my friend's regular white rice, and that was cooked in chicken broth and really, really good (unlike brown rice, which is just plain).
author: Ke C.

description: Best Hai Nam chicken spot in San Francisco. The chicken is perfectly poached, tender, boneless and with the skin on! The rice is fragrant and prefect in texture and the side of soup is so good.
author: Viet P.

description:
New to SOMA and that sauce is AMAZING! made with fresh chili, ginger, garlic and soybean sauce, absolutely delicious! And the rice was cook perfectly. I can just eat the rice and the sauce alone. Yum! I got the original, with both white and dark meat. Garish with cucumbers. You can add veggies of the day for extra $3. Small menu but its great because chicken and rice is all you need. 

I got there at 1:10pm and there was no wait. I ordered my food and got my order in under 5 mins. Quick and efficient. There is also outside and inside seating.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Khao Mun Gai for the first time! It's amazingly delicious. The time I went, I got the original with an egg. The original comes with a nice amount of chicken, rice, some cucumbers, a cup of soup, and a small container of soybean sauce. 

While I didn't end up eating my food here, I will begin by looking at the ambience of the location. The ambience seems pretty modern. Your experience begins when you enter the front doors and you see a pretty minimal menu, which in my books is an A+, since minimal menus allow for less "decision fatigue". I also liked the interior design, since the colors weren't very distracting from the whole experience (yes, my whole experience of waiting for my food to-go haha). There is also a courtyard outside of this restaurant, giving you another option if you think the indoor seating is too claustrophobic. 

On to the food! I think what stood out the most to me was the soup; there was just so much flavor, that I probably would have been happy if I had just drunk that (well flavor-wise). The soybean sauce (from which I tasted garlic and ginger, as some of the more prominent flavors) was also something worth mentioning, as it gave an interesting kick to the chicken. 

All in all, I would definitely come back here again, and probably more often too, if it weren't a 15 minute walk away from my workplace.


Photo I took (Instagram):
https://www.instagram.com/p/BYytElLBObT (Original)
https://www.instagram.com/p/BasPORrBBej/
https://www.instagram.com/p/BcGFCpFB48E/
author: Ed W.

description: I like this place's focus on doing one thing right.. but I just don't think that their signature dish is exactly perfect. I grew up eating boiled chicken and rice (in Chinese this dish is usually called Hainan chicken rice) and while I like their packaged convenience, I thought that the convenience was the best part. I tried both the thigh and breast meat, regular and paleo versions, and I'm not sure I would pay $11-13 dollars for them again. Also, while I thought the sauce was fine, I don't think it's as good as the Cantonese style ginger+green onion in oil sauce that had a sharper, cleaner punch. I'm not a food purist when it comes to tradition.. I just didn't think this place was that great.
author: Jean L.

description: It's simple and just soooo good. It may be a little pricey but again it's San Francisco so I don't really mind
author: Jackie T.

description:
You can't come here expecting Hawker Stall style chicken, but you can expect to a good fast, healthy and tasty meal. 

For ~$14, paleo chicken comes with a hefty portion of breast or thigh meat, some cucumbers (not pickled, sad) and steamed broccoli. It also comes with chicken broth and ginger soy sauce. 

The chicken here is moist, though it's not the typical Singaporean super fatty salty chicken type broth, with almost creamy rice. Nonetheless, I'm a huge fan and an even bigger fan of the outdoor seating. 

Tip: line seems to get massive around 1215!
author: Kristie C.

description:
Easy. Macro-Friendly. Meal. Ever.

However, it may be seen as a little on the pricier end as you're paying about $12 / 14 for rice and chicken / or tofu when comparing to your typical rice and chicken / tofu plates elsewhere. The quality seems pretty fresh and the rice is very flavorful - a little on the saltier end for my taste but I'd still come back.

They do get pretty busy as most people order delivery so just be prepared to be patient.
author: Cheri C.

description:
Rooster & Rice's expansion into the FiDi was clever, especially in time for the Year of the Rooster. After all, which millennial wouldn't be able to resist an expensive but photogenic lunch with a clever fitting Instagram caption! (Yes I am aware that I am making fun of myself)

R&R illustrates my love-hate relationship with the SF food scene--it's delicious, wholesome, high-quality, global-inspired, but borders on downright unaffordable. My counter-service lunch of chicken over rice with sauce, cucumbers, and broccoli (an extra $2) totaled to $15.18! In Asia, you could probably serve the same dish to a small family at the same cost. 

Price rants aside, R&R creates an excellent rendition of Hainan chicken rice. My SF cynicism expected a gentrified version that would lose the original flavors and toss in random avocados and stuff (I do laugh at their poached egg option), but the complex flavors and superb quality exceeded my expectations. My favorite turned out to be the rice: the robust, fragrant chicken flavoring was memorable, and the unconventional amount of al dente-ness was a pleasant surprise. The sauce brought everything together in layers of sweet soy sauce blended with ginger, scallions, beans, and chili. I also opted for some habanero sauce (mainly to make my picture look more colorful), which added a mild creaminess.

Because of the distractingly good sauces, I found it difficult to evaluate the chicken itself. The chicken in this dish is always intentionally plain so you can fully appreciate the chicken essence. I think the use of Mary's chicken inherently has a different chicken-ness compared to the "yellow-haired chicken" (黃毛雞) traditionally used, so it's difficult to evaluate the poaching technique. The chicken broth was richly flavored and steamy, the perfect heart-warming addition to any lunch in chilly SF days.

Note that although it ins't your typical greasy food, the liberal use of chicken fat and various sauces make it a more filling lunch than you'd expect from a chicken meal. For me, it also left a bit of a salty aftertaste.

The space is hipster--upbeat almost-rap-like music, impressive arrangements of succulents, communal tables of course. Outside there's a beautiful public open space courtyard. 

The verdict? Yummy food, quite authentic, with a Californian flair, but at Marina prices.
author: Edna C.

description:
I've been to the Marina location and liked it a lot, so was very glad there's now a location close to me. Came on a Monday night around 6, and waited over thirty minutes for my food after ordering. I was pretty mad, but we received a sincere apology, got an explanation for why the food was late, and was offered free drinks when we finally got our food. I think most of the time when people are pissed off about bad service, they really just want an apology and explanation. 

In terms of food, I thought the chicken was just slightly dry, but the sauce totally makes up for it though. It's got a tinge of sweetness and not all oil like some of the other places, and I only wish there was more of it. The rice is super soft and not too greasy, and definitely try both hot sauces!
author: Julie Z.

description:
YESSSS. Kao mun gai is my favorite Thai dish ever (and is very much a staple meal choice in Thailand) but sadly is not that well known or offered in Thai restaurants in the US. I'm so glad Rooster & Rice opened a second location close to where I work to share this amazingness with America! My cousin and I are both of Thai descent and went to this restaurant to see what the hype was about. Actually I was just really craving some kao mun gai and Rooster & Rice delivered! 

We got the original and were both very impressed. Portions were generous. Chicken was tender and flavorful. The rice, OH THE RICE, gave off a light, fragrant scent of jasmine combined with the mouth watering flavor of chicken broth. The highlight and real test was THE SAUCE. This is always the trickiest part to get right but the portions of the ingredients really hit the spot. Sigh... I love kao mun gai. 

We came the day after opening around lunch time so there was a delay in getting our orders out - I think they were waiting for the rice to cook. The owners acknowledged the delay and even offered to give us a free drink, but their generosity and that acknowledgement was all I needed. Thanks for being awesome and opening your doors to SOMA!

Pros
-Kao mun gai, duh!

Cons
-Kinda pricey, but it's soo goood
author: Grace J.

description:
Great place to eat if you're looking for something healthy!

I came here for dinner and there was basically no wait but I do hear lunch time gets pretty packed. I ordered the original with white rice and it came with a little cup of soup. If you want any add ons though, be prepared to pay 30% more...

However, overall it was very simple and filling! The soy bean sauce paired very well with the chicken and rice combo. The rice was very flavorful and the chicken had a good texture.  Overall a good meal! The downside is that it is relatively expensive for just chicken and rice but that's kind of the norm with restaurants in SOMA.
author: Angela P.

description:
Simple, yet delicious dish with chicken soup 
 
On the side, you can try the chicken skin. it's an unhealthy option, but it's too good to resist.

Five stars in general! Will come back at least once a month.

Recommend coming before noon or after one to dodge the lunch crowd.
author: Lit K.

description:
Given the area this shop is in, it's not surprising that it's a bit spendy given what you get, but there's no denying that this is authentic Hainanese-style chicken, with the right sauces to match.

The portions are rather modest, but that's probably a good thing if you're watching both the quantity and quality of what you eat. It's honest-to-goodness chicken served on a bed of rice.

It's all short, simple, and satisfying. Service is also fast and efficient too.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Tucked away in the corner of the plaza of 303 2nd Street, Rooster & Rice is a booming new craze in the South of Market area of San Francisco. During lunch hours the line is straight out the door, but this is expected as SoMa is chock-full of busy, urban professionals. Clean and modern feel on the inside. You order at the cashier and wait for your name to be called, and you can either grab a seat at a table/bartop or take it to-go.

Menu doesn't seem diverse, but each chicken-over-rice (or vegetables) combo has its own unique flair. I usually get the Marina -- breast, skinless over brown rice -- and it's amazing! Love the broth on the side, too. I was in there for days at a time when I went to work sick (-: They provide a garlic soybean sauce with the order, but you can also add this orange hot sauce on the side. The meal is super light and I don't hate myself afterwards. A weekly ritual!
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Good food, price and portion. This Thai dish is very similar to hainan chicken in Singapore, but the sauce is different. The sauce here is mildly spicy and sweet. The rice is marinated in the chicken sauce. 

Bonus is that they use take out containers that is biodegradable and compost in 20 days. From the portions, take out container and luxurious napkins, the owners seems like generous and caring people.
author: Gloria T.

description:
As the name suggests, the specialities of this place are chicken & rice.

I got the Paleo Bowl which came with chicken, seasonal veggies (broccoli when I went), cucumbers, and a cup of chicken broth. I got a mix of thigh & breast meat, and my it was so unbelievably tender. The chicken flavorful and super juicy. The price is a bit steep since it was $12.95 and after tax, about $14. However, they use organic Mary's chicken and the chicken was indeed a enormous portion. The broth was super flavorful and tasted like the kind of broth my mom would stew with chicken bones and make me drink when I was sick as a kid. Definitely use the ginger garlic soybean dipping sauce that comes with it too!

The original bowl come with chicken & white jasmine rice, the Marina comes with brown, and there is also a vegetarian option that subs the chicken with organic tofu. You can also do add ons for a few dollars more, such as adding an egg. It's a great healthy lunch option or even post-workout meal. Over all it's a bit pricey for a meal, but the quality and portion sizes are worth it.
author: Joy W.

description:
This place is simply delicious! Great for lunch, they are super quick and nice service. Their poached chicken is perfectly cooked (I hate when you chew chicken and two seconds later it becomes saw dust in your mouth.) they give you about 6-8 oz. of chicken. I've had both the original and paleo which was both served with chicken broth and cucumbers. (Can't go wrong with either chicken breast or chicken thigh) I personally love when dishes are served with a bit of freshly cut cucumbers, makes the meal taste clean and fresh. Their side of ginger sauce is lightly sweet and perfect to pour over the whole dish or dip separately. They also have a sriracha (standard) and a habanero sauce. The habanero sauce is definitely spicey but not overbearing which gives the dish a really nice kick to it. 

The place is small, but there is a ton of seating outside and on a nice day, it's generally preferred. For $13, I'd say it's worth it. I always feel full, but not the gross kind of full that makes you feel sluggish and want a nap after. This place is definitely my go to lunch spot.
author: Christine T.

description:
*** In Short ***

Tasty and accessible Thai chicken rice in an area all-too-lacking in Asian food.

*** In Depth ***

If you've never had khao man gai, it's the Thai take on Hainan chicken rice: similar in preparation, but with a slightly different flavor profile. Simple, but somewhat time-consuming to make, Rooster & Rice finally brought what it had to offer to SoMa, after a successful start in the Marina. And thank god they did, because this part of town has always been a bit lacking in solid Asian eats!

There's not much else to say here other than that they've done a great job capturing both the flavor and simplicity of this comfort food, serving up tender and moist chicken, with an equally flavorful side of chicken broth to pair. Of course, expect the typical SF tax on what is traditionally a pretty cheap eat, but hey, that comes with the territory, right?

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A smaller shop with plenty of seating in the courtyard outside, the only real accessibility issue you might face here is reaching their hot sauces, which are usually on a pretty high shelf above another counter. That, and carrying about your soup without spilling it.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Food = good. Fresh and clean tasting.

The Original = breast & thigh skin-on with Jasmine white rice. Tender and juicy breast and thigh--they're both so good. Habanero sauce in addition to their awesome (chili, ginger, garlic & soybean) sauce makes this chicken & rice dish even more epic. Chicken broth comes with the entree and it's delicious. Piping hot, not crazy salty and actually tastes like, well, chicken. $11.95. 

I added an egg. Because why not. $2.00. 

They also have fried chicken skins ($5.00) but they were out after 1 p.m. Maybe next time... 

Service = friendly at the counter. Everything else is self-service. And almost everything is compostable/biodegradable.

Prices = moderate. Lunch came out to $15.14. Probably would've had leftovers if I hadn't waited so long to have lunch. There's plenty to eat though.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I'm a HUGEEE fan of chicken and rice dishes, particularly Hainan chicken rice. When I saw this place popped up, I knew I had to pay it a visit! After a long day at work, I was really craving something simple and delicious and Rooster & Rice was just around the corner. 

I have never had Khao Mun Gai, which is a Thai version of Hainanese chicken rice, but I have had Hainanese chicken rice countless times in the past. I ordered their Original (around $12 with tax). Their Original is a combination of chicken thigh and breast all boneless on a wonderful bed of fragrant rice with a side of chicken broth. The Asian me screams thigh meat is the way to go for all chicken dishes since chicken breasts are often super dry and tasteless. However, their chicken breast meat super tender, flavorful, and juicy. When I took a bite of their chicken with a scoop of the rice with a little bit of their habanero hot sauce, I was in full chicken heaven bliss. Not only is their chicken good, but the rice is packed with chicken oils and flavor. I have not tasted a chicken rice this flavorful in a very long time. Many Chinese places serve Hainanese chicken rice, but most of them fail to deliver juicy chicken and flavorful rice. This place has PERFECTED their chicken and their rice. 

Once I took the first bite of this mega flavorful chicken and rice, I couldn't stop myself from finishing the entire box. Put some of their housemade sweet, sour, garlicky, gingery sauce and the housemade habanero sauce onto the chicken rice to give it the most perfect spice and flavorful kick. If you find yourself in need of some veggies, you can crunch on little pieces of cucumber that are given as a side. If you want to wash down your chicken rice with some liquid, you can drink their super flavorful chicken broth. You will be in full chicken heaven!!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
This is an instant favorite. I'm not really into the healthy food craze (mainly because most places I've tried really sacrifice on taste and/or service), but this is just one of the best restaurants I've tried recently, healthy or otherwise.

They have a simple menu, matching the simple and modern layout of the location. I think that's good because it keeps things simple, but refined and focused. 

I'm partial to the original. Each of the ingredients are incredibly flavorful and complement each other well. They don't skimp on portions either, which means you'll be satisfied at the end of your meal. 

There may be a bit of a line depending on when you visit, but they get the meals out quickly. 

It's a little more expensive than I want to pay for a regular meal, but the quality is well worth it. If you're looking for something new, healthy, and quick, definitely check this place out.
author: Daniel M.

description:
This spot is absolutely, 100% different in almost every way from their Marina location. Super nice decor, much much more seating, white walls, and even fresh coconuts (never seen them at other location). Cater to your customers though. 

We ended up grabbing the Original with double chicken which was a nice amount on top of what already comes with. Pretty good food. Good rice. Good soup. Chicken is cool, however my chicken was cold. Everything else was hot, even my girlfriend's full plate was hot. I was disappointed that my chicken was cold. I wanted to say something but the guy behind the register kept disappearing behind the wall so wasn't sure if he was cashier/chef/clean-up crew. 

Besides the chicken being cold I like this spot. 3 stars for that.
author: John M.

description:
This is my comfort food right here. It's good and I enjoyed the sauce. The rice isn't what I would get in Thailand but I wasn't expecting it to taste exactly the same anyways. It's futile to compare.

The oddest feeling was to eat this dish with a fork! I have never had this dish without the use of a spoon before. Weird, huh?
author: Yad L.

description: Same great chicken as the Marina location, with significantly worse service. The cashier and a person in the back were looking at Tinder profiles together when I showed up, and it took a solid minute for them to disengage. As I was eating, I noticed that they took their Tinder swiping to the back, even though there were people waiting to be served. Great chicken, but don't expect a friendly experience.
author: Christina S.

description:
Rooster & Rice is a great new option for lunch in SoMa that replaced the old Urban Picnic location (thank goodness).

With a young staff and menu that's humbly only 4 items long, it's easy to like this unassuming but friendly restaurant.

Somehow, the 4 options are each individually delicious, extendable through add-ons, and can accommodate most diets: vegetarians and paleo/keto folks should have no issue here. With such an easy menu, the kitchen is able to pump out boxes with no problem.

The chicken, stock, poached eggs and rice are made in bulk in the back, and each well-cooked and surprisingly authentic. I only had two gripes both times I visited: 1) the chicken skin was chewy and 2) the box and dish were lukewarm.

Be warned though - the line can start going out the door around noon every day, so it's advisable to come a bit before or after the lunch rush.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
This place is AMAZING. Not sure if it's because of the nostalgia this dish brings to me (my family cooked this my whole life) or if it's just that damn good but I had it twice on my trip to San Francisco even though I had a long list of places I wanted to visit. It's just THAT good. 

I ordered the original both times. The meat is so moist and the sauce that comes with it is BOMB. Would highly recommend this!
author: Michelle L.

description: I love how simple, clean and fresh the ingredients are at Rooster & Rice. The broth on the side is a nice touch and i love that the veggies are fresh and still have a bit of a crunch to them. The chicken is poached to perfection: flavorful and tender.
author: Danielle D.

description: Favorite chicken in sf so far! Really like the chicken soup！Of course will go there again
author: Ying C.

description: I came here on a weekday evening and it wasn't super full but there were people. The chairs outside are chained to the table so we opted to sit inside. I ordered #1, and the chicken was very tender and juicy but there was a lot of skin/fat/black veins? or whatever it is. The sauce was good and so was the soup, but the rice was quite soggy and not very chewy. The cucumber was a nice addition though I wish there were more vegetables. The portions were really big though; it was a lot of chicken! At $13.54 post-tax, I guess this is on par with SF prices, but I'd say it's a bit pricey for chicken, sauce, rice, and soup.
author: Andrea W.

description: Came here randomly last time I was in San Francisco. Surprisingly good hainanese chicken over rice. Don't forget to add the egg on top, you won't regret it! Compared to some restaurants I usually go to in Chinatown, it's a bit on the pricier end, but the portions are huge and it's enough to fill you up.
author: Calvin L.

description:
I love rooster and rice. The food is so cozy, simple and filling. The chicken is always well cooked and tasty and goes well with the rice and the sauce. The portions are sizeable as well. The broth, to be honest, is probably the best part of the meal. Amazing!
Although, this place is a bit expensive and the wait times can get a bit crazy depending on the time of day.
author: Leelakrishna N.

description:
This place has a very simple menu, which I like. Chicken and rice, that's it (save for a vegetarian option).

My companion and I ordered the original rooster bowl and a vegetarian bowl. They come with little cups of soup on the side! My chicken broth was light and delicious.

At first glance, the chicken looks cold and flavorless, but looks can be deceiving. The meat was very tender, but the sauce was the real star, mixed with a little of the habanero sauce for a spicy kick. Very good. The only thing I didn't really like was the skin that they left on the meat- I'm not a big fan of chewy skin but to teach their own.

 The veggie bowl was fine, but the chicken was better imo. Also we ordered an extra egg, which turned out to be poached, not fried. The eggs were kind of inconsistent in that one still had a runny yolk, while the other was completely solidified. A little weird, but it didn't really bother me.

The seating is very minimal. Server was very nice and polite, but it took a while to get our order. Overall, probably a 4.5.
author: Jane H.

description: The Jasemine rice is NOT VEGETARIAN. Food is good, but from the dozens of times I've been here I've never been told that the Jasemine rice was cooked with chicken broth. Severely disappointed in this company for not better informing their customers.
author: Kyoko L.

description: The secret delight is definitely in the sauce. Inexplicably delicious, it contains many things from small beans, garlic, ginger, green onions, vinegar, shoyu, to many other tangy things that go well with fresh steamed broccoli, cucumber slices, protein of your choice (tofu, chicken, etc), and brown rice. Simple and healthy take-out meals with fairly standard ingredients are made spectacular by the sauces. $1 more for an additional spicy orange sauce. Takeout and delivery option available. A bit on the pricey side for each dish ($11-$13, not including add ons like egg), but it's healthy and again, they deliver to the office.
author: Alison A.

description:
I love your portions, your rice, your chicken, your sous-vide egg, and your broth. It's as close to Savoy Kitchen or Green Zone from SoCal that I can get in the Bay Area. 

Also your paper napkins are luxurious! Holy crap, one of our to-go broths leaked in my fridge because of my fault (I didn't snap on the lid fully after opening it) and the next day I opened the fridge, the napkins absorbed all of the soup. Can't be good for the environment but appreciate having such quality napkins.

But food is better than napkins so gonna end it on that note.
author: Jayson V.

description: The original chicken rice tastes good. The chicken soup that comes with the main dish is delicious too. I would recommend.
author: Yinrong L.

description:
Simple and straight forward. Wanted more cucumbers/veggies with my order, but will keep that in mind for next time (guess I'll have to ask for extra?). I got The Marina which comes with skinless chicken breast & brown rice. Sauce was good, went well with the chicken & rice which were also very good. Broth also good. Great customer service. Quick and easy pick up after my workout nearby.

Other:
They don't have Apple Pay, despite what the info says.
author: Kelley P.

description: Yummy! My gf just brought over to-go for our lunch date. I had The Paleo with thigh meat. Super soft texture over a bed of crunchy broccoli, side dipping sauce and soup. Healthy protein lunch and big portion. Will try out different order next time.
author: Vee V.

description:
I LOVE Hainan food... In particular the chicken. I was recommend to this place by the Fung Bros (you can find them on YouTube). You would've never known that the restaurant is located where it's at. It is a bit hidden but keep walking near the perimeter of the building and you're bound to find it. 

Unfortunately we came here about 30 mins before closing so it was our fault we came here so late. There was 4 of us but they only have enough chicken for 3 orders. As bummed out as we were, we ended up getting all of the food anyways. The cashier was nice and saw the disappointment on my face, he gave a small percentage of discount and through in some soup with our order for free. (*soup is extra charge)

What can I say about Rooster and Rice?... it's simple and it's exceptionally healthy or at least it taste healthy in a good way. The portions were enough for one person (sadly, I had to share with someone else...again MY fault). I would definitely come back and get my own plate next time! :)
author: Kaleigh R.

description: One of those...ITS THE BEST KHAO MUN GAI IN SF places because I really haven't been to any other khao mun gai only place in sf.  A bit pricey but I don't even know what that means in SF anymore maybe because I'm poor and can't keep up with the rich kids.
author: Vince L.

description: Love everything about Rooster & Rice. This is my boyfriend and my go-to spot for a weekday quick dinner. Luckily, they are open until 8 PM Monday-Fridays (unlike a lot of other restaurants in the area that are generally only open for the lunch crowd). Rooster & Rice uses Mary's Chicken (you can get breast or thighs) over jasmine rice (or you can get brown rice). They always give you a side broth as well (usually very hot, so I would let it cool down a bit first). This spot is more of a to-go spot, but there are a few tables. Their spicy sauce is super good, but warning-a little goes a long way, so don't be dumping it on! It is your typical SF price point, but definitely a filling meal! I definitely recommend!
author: Kim C.

description:
The chicken: I ordered "The Original" and the cashier kindly let me substitute brown rice. The chicken was good! Big portion! Well poached! Would have been a LOT better if the chicken had been topped off with the cilantro that appears on every damn photo on Yelp and on the R&R website. I love cilantro. But... cilantro, denied.

The brown rice: Big portion, freshly prepared. Would have been better with cilantro. I fell for the old "Cilantro Bait & Switch" and it hurt.

The dipping sauce: Awesome, awesome. Love the generous amounts of ginger. Oh, hey, I think I saw a fleck of cilantro in the sauce. Nice try, R&R, but you still owe me a generous helping of cilantro. 

It's a pricey lunch, but for healthfully prepared chicken, brown rice, and killer sauce, it's a great high-protein/good-carb meal. But I'm keeping a cilantro ledger, and R&R is in the RED.
author: Jon P.

description: Deceivingly simple but really tasty chicken and rice bowls.  I was a bit skeptical at first, but demolished my lunch in record time today.  The chicken was tender, the jasmine rice was aromatic - but the whole dish comes together owing to the tasty soy ginger sauce, which is a riff off of classic Asian/Chinese flavor profile (chicken + ginger).  The chicken broth side was a teeny tiny too salty, but still delish.  This location has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating, but it's still best to come on the early side of the lunch hour.
author: Tabitha G.

description:
Rooster and Rice serves hainan style chicken and rice. It's a really simple poached chicken dish with some fragrant rice and sauce (soy, ginger and garlic). Besides the vegetarian option, each dish comes with a side of chicken broth. The place is pretty small and gets crowded during lunch so it's better to order it to go. 

It's simple but man do they do it well, it's one of those comfort foods that you can have every day and not really get bored of it. 

My go to order is The Original ($12) plus a poached egg ($2). The runny egg over rice just makes it that much better. They have a house habanero sauce that packs a nice kick that I add as well.

I know people complain about the price being high, but being in SF and comparing it to a $15 salad, it really isn't that bad. My only complaint is that it's not closer to where I work. 

Tip:
Some days they fry up the chicken skins and have it available for $5, if you're with a group it is worth sharing
author: Vijay S.

description: Such a solid spot for lunch! Chicken and rice prepared the hainan style is definitely comfort food for me and this spot delivers! It might be on the bland side for people who are unsure of what to expect, but to me, the light flavors of the broth and chicken are a perfect combination along with the sweet/savory cilantro/ginger/garlic sauce that it all comes with. It's a healthy and fast meal that is great on a cold day!
author: Annie S.

description:
Great lunch spot in SOMA!

I have heard people raving about this place long before I tried it out myself. To be honest, I was very skeptical about this back then, but now I'm hooked! The photos do not do them justice. Yes, it might look kind of bland. Yes, it might seem somewhat small-portioned. But the chicken and rice combo tastes wonderful and is surprisingly fulfilling. I love "The Original" and "The Paleo" w/ an egg. The chicken soup they always give out as a side is delicious too. It does tend to be pricier than other lunch places in the area (~$13-15), but I would say it's worth to try out.

P.S. I find the actual restaurant area smell really funny, but none of my coworkers are picking up on that... so it might just be me. Food is great though!
author: Angel C.

description:
BUYER BEWARE!!! 

Just bought an "original" chicken and rice bowl from this hole in the wall and was shocked with what I found! My bowl consisted of about 70% chicken skin and fat and 30% meat which is unreal for a $12 lunch IMO. I mean this place cleary wants you to be sickened by their original so they can price gouge you on the Marina "healthy" option for 2 dollars more! I posted a photo of what I believe is chicken skin on this yelp review. That is all I am going to rant for now but never going back after my experience here.
author: Kazmo V.

description: Solid lunch spot to eat a light and healthy meal. When Rooster & Rice first opened, the food was superb. It was flavorful, juicy, and the chicken meat was smooth. It also didn't feel too heavy and was balanced. After going back a few times, I feel like the quality dipped slightly. The chicken tasted more bland and the texture was less smooth. It's still good though, but doesn't live up to when it first opened. That's why I'm docking one star.
author: Amanda T.

description: A simple, tasty, filling, healthy meal close to work!? Sign me up! While I do find it a bit expensive for essentially chicken and rice, I still think it's worth it in terms of flavor. I certainly can't make chicken this juicy and tender at home haha (sorry to my future s/o). I may gripe about the price, but I certainly don't let it keep me from coming back over and over again!
author: Alice L.

description:
Yum!  As the restaurant's name suggests, this place literally has only rice and chicken haha.  The location is tucked away in the plaza so it was nice and quiet when we came in around 3p. 

I ordered the original with dark meat only and added an egg.  The dish came with soy sauce mix on the side and a bowl of chicken broth. I was nervous to pour the entire cup of soy sauce but it worked out perfectly. To my surprise, the dish wasn't too salty even with all the soy sauce.  I'm glad I chose to get all dark meat because the meat came out juicy and flavorful (not dry at all).  The addition of the egg gave the rice a creamy texture -not creamy in a weird way.  The cucumber and cilantro gave the dish a refreshing kick. If I were to get this dish next time, I would opt to get it without the skin. I wasn't a fan of the mushy skin (for some reason I thought the skin would be crunchy lmao).  The chicken broth went soo well with the rice. Such an Asian combo :) aka the rice x broth. I never knew this was a Thai dish and I'm glad a place like this exists!  Overall, Rooster and Rice was very memorable!  10/10 recommend. 

Oh, grab a Thai tea while you're at it!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Nestled in a shopping plaza located in SOMA, lies Rooster and Rice.  The place gets crowded during lunch, but with a simplistic menu that only offers a few things, the line should move quickly.  There are plenty of seats inside, but if every spot is taken, there are still lots of places to sit outside.  

Rooster & Rice does live up to the hype, but it comes with a price tag.  My rice box ended up costing me a whopping $16.22.  I ordered ​"The Marina" which comes with all skinless breast, and organic brown rice.  I also added an egg to my order.  

I waited several minutes for my order, and decided to load up on sauce at the condiment and utensils area.  You are also able to purchase sauce at the counter, but why would you if it is free here?  They also have really good quality napkins here too!  I guess you could say that is why a rice box costs so much here?  

After grabbing a seat, I decided to try the chicken without any sauce first.  I took a bite, and the meat was ultra soft-- melt in your mouth type quality.  However, there was no seasoning whatsoever.  It tasted so boring and plain.  I decided to try the next bite with the spicy sauce and the ginger garlic sauce. The flavors were a fusion of multiple parties in my mouth.  Needless to say, it was delicious.  The brown rice was cooked well.  The egg was a little under for my liking.  The chicken broth that comes with the meal was amazing.  I thoroughly enjoyed how flavorful it was.  

In conclusion, this place is good.  However, this is something I would not get every day.  For $16, I could get three rice boxes in Chinatown.  I would consider trying this place at least once though  because it is very unique.
author: Victor L.

description:
VERY good chicken rice, also the soup is very very yummy.
Dipping sauce and averything else just perfect.
Just little bit in high price.
author: Gatot T.

description:
New favorite lunch spot in the city! Rooster & Rice serves only khao man gai, which is quite literally just boiled chicken and rice. Don't underestimate the flavors of khao man gai, however. In my opinion, khao man gai is the better version of Hainanese chicken since it comes with a flavorful soy sauce and side of soup. Honestly, I think Rooster & Rice does khao man gai much better than Kin Khao, which has a Michelin star. At least, I would hope so, since that's all they serve.

My recommendation is to eat the dish by dipping the chicken into the soy sauce. If you pour it all over, I think it'd be too salty. The portion is huge, even if it is a little expensive - I can definitely split it into two meals. They also have Thai sriracha and habanero sauce available for you to take as you please (I prefer the habanero). They have a vegetarian version, which has tofu instead of chicken and seasonal vegetables. 

Overall wait is very short and the inside of the restaurant is cute too!

I think my only complaint with Rooster & Rice is that I wish they gave more cucumbers in their original khao man gai, but I just really love cucumbers, so I finished them all before I even ate half of the chicken.

Anyways, I definitely recommend checking Rooster & Rice out for lunch! It's definitely a place that I can see myself frequenting a couple times a month.
author: Trisha V.

description:
I had my first taste of Thai chicken rice last year in Portland at Nong's. Ever since, I've been waiting for something like it to open in SF. And then the illustrious Year of the Rooster came around and brought Rooster & Rice with it. I knew this would be a good year. 

Rooster & Rice has made itself a staple of my weekly lunches and that's because it heavily satisfies two of the three qualities I look for in a weekday lunch- delicious, and quick (if you show up before 12). Unfortunately it's not that cheap as you'll be forking over at least $15 for your meal. 

I've gotten both the "Original" and the "Marina" and they are amazing. The chicken is tender, the rice filling, and the sauce herby. I saw some people dipping their chicken into the sauce but the true secret to unlocking the taste of your meal is to pour the sauce over your chicken. Your meal will taste much better with the sauce permeating every nook and cranny of your plate. 

Finally, I want to give a shout out to the soup they throw in with your meal. This is the kind of soup you drank in college to cure hangovers. These days, I drink this soup to cure bad mornings at work.
author: Philip W.

description:
The lines will be long, but it goes by fast and it's worth it, yo!

You will be spending about $15+ on lunch though, no doubt. But that lunch will be filled with juicy, healthy chicken on a bed of delicious rice served with a little cup of bone broth. Healthy, filling and oh so satisfying. What gets ya is the additional add-on's, pricewise. Want extra veggies? $3. Want an egg? $3. Goodbye are the days of cheap eats for lunch.

Order the original with white rice, the marina with brown rice, the paleo with seasonal veggies in lieu of rice or the vegetarian, tofu in lieu of that chicken.

They have a tasty soy based sauce to pour on and don't forget your little cups of sriracha or what looks to be housemade habanero. If you're gonna drop $15+ on lunch, this is a great option.

Plenty of outside seating both with tables and chairs, but also some funky seating in the courtyard; perfect for a sunny San Francisco day.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: It's good but bland compared to the real thing in Singapore, also pricey but not unexpected in the area. I do like their paleo option. Thanks
author: Tiff W.

description:
It took me a while to figure this place out, so let me break it down for you.

You need to get the ​The Original. It's dope. And you know it's real chicken because sometimes the thighs still have sharp ass bones in them. Second best option is the The Marina if you don't want to stab yourself potentially with bones. Chicken, however, is aces either way. You cannot go wrong with chicken at a place called Rooster & Rice.

What you need to do is request the addition of veggies. It's extra. I do not understand why their main dish doesn't come with a single piece of veggie (which happened the first time I ordered here), but you need something to balance all that dry ass rice and delicious sauce. 

Once everything's done, you'll quickly realize it's almost too much food for one sitting. My tip, carve out the section that you want to eat and plan to save it for another late night meal.

That way, your overpriced $17 San Francisco lunch won't feel like robbery. Although it is, don't kid yourself.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Walked in at 2:50pm, they were playing T-shirt by Migos, the place was empty except for this one dude waiting for food that kept giving me a smolder-smile which was a little weird but it's all good because I then ordered a paleo with half veggies half rice and both chicken breast and thigh. Food was ready in like 3 minutes. I was thinking about sitting inside--they had cool succulents and other chaparral-ish flora to examine but it was 82 degrees and my top peeled off (jk it was like 60 and i had my jacket off) so I sat outside (lots of seating options). 

The food is not as good as the one on FILBERT but still decent. The rice is more flavorful (and sticky) but the chicken is less hainan and more bland. They didn't give me half rice half veggie (more rice than veggie) but I'm fine with that. The sauce here has more sauce than ingredients but overall similar tastes. The chicken also had a lot of skin in comparison to the ones I got at filbert.

Subtle differences between the two locations: the one on filbert tastes more high-quality but the location on 2nd is convenient and has a ton of seating options.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Yes! A super healthy option right next to my office in SOMA. They serve exactly what I have been making at home, whenever I want to eat right -
Protein, Brown Rice, Veggies. Done. And, they have a nice habanero sauce available that made me happy. I read several reviews before going so I was okay paying ~$15. As many have said, welcome to San Francisco. I give it 5 stars because of the napkins - I hate it when a place charges a lot and then has those flimsy useless napkins that disintegrate in your hands. R&R has these wonderful plush, towel like napkins. Nice touch.
author: James L.

description:
Pretty interesting Thai chicken and rice place. I've been here a few times for lunch. The wait is never really more than 5 mins, probably because what you're getting is literally boiled chicken and rice. 

I was a bit skeptical at first that the food would be too bland but the little container of sauce they provide adds a huge kick of flavour. In fact, it might even be too much. My main problem with the sauce is the big chunks of ginger. I'd prefer the ginger to be blended in a bit better and not so overpowering. But I'm sure some people actually love the ginger overload. 

Also, $13+ feels like a lot to pay for essentially boiled chicken and rice, even for SF, but hey, it's certainly fresh and flavourful. Also, it's perfect as a post-workout meal!
author: Sahil S.

description:
Rooster & Rice is now one of my favorite places to eat in the area!! I just wish this place opens on weekends too... then my life would be complete.

I actually live nearby but don't work in the area, so I always request my boyfriend to bring home a bowl for me... I love all the sauces they offer. It's also really filling and good enough for two meals when I cook some veggies on the side to go along with it.
author: Janet H.

description:
As everyone seems to agree, this place is a solid four stars. Great place to get a filling and (relatively) healthy meal in downtown. Rooster & Rice serves a Thai variation of Hainanese chicken rice, which features juicy, tender chicken over rice, combined with a very flavorful soy-based sauce. The portion size is generous and will leave you feeling satisfied. It also comes with chicken broth on the side, which is lightly flavored and comforting.

The menu is short, featuring only a few variants of chicken rice with clever names like "The Marina" -- a healthier skinless chicken option over brown rice. As a result, the line moves quickly, so don't be intimidated by what looks like a long wait.

Docking a star because it's so pricy, but I'll probably still make my way over every now and then, because the chicken rice really is that good.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Finally got to try Rooster & Rice after having the Marina location bookmarked for months, and I was not disappointed! Came here with my friends one rainy day for lunch and it was completely packed - we ended up taking our food to go because there was nowhere to sit. We all had the original, chicken breast and thigh with skin over jasmine rice, which also comes with a small bowl of delicious soup. The chicken itself was incredibly tender and flavorful, and even better with the ginger sauce that comes with it (even though I had to pick out all the leaves of cilantro). There are also two more sauces you can serve yourself, but the spicy orange one is better than the red tangy one. 

The price was pretty reasonable especially considering portion size because I was quite full after devouring the entire box. I just wish they had a bigger space with more seating, but there are many public spaces in the area where you can take your food to go. Though the menu is very simple, the quality of food is top notch and well worth the wait. Definitely will be back in the future to satisfy my Hainan chicken cravings!
author: KC W.

description:
Stopped by for lunch on a Wednesday. Beat the lunch crowd by arriving before noon! 

Menu is very basic, usually a base (rice, salad) with a choice of meat (chicken/pork/beef). The sauce that comes with it is really good. I got the chicken bowl, which comes with some pickled? vegetables and the sauce and rice. It was pretty cheap for the amount of food I got. 

There is a lot of outdoor seating in that courtyard area. Good spot for lunch on weekdays.
author: RachEl L.

description: New lunch spot in SOMA and I'm a fan!  It's located in the same plaza as Red Dog.  The menu is simple- just chicken & rice or chicken & veggies with a side of chicken broth.  Who knew chicken and rice can taste so good and be satisfying?  It must be that ginger soy based sauce!  They also offer a side of the habanero and siracha sauce as well to complement your meal.  Seating is limited and there is usually a line out the door during lunch but it goes fairly quick.  A great "Asian" alternative to the area.
author: Melanie N.

description:
IT'S SOOOOOOOOO GOOOOOD!!!

But seriously though, I just finished it a few minutes ago and now I have very conflicting feelings. I'm super happy because I just had an amazing lunch. I'm also super sad because I'm done and there's no more. Are these tears tears of joy or tears of sadness, or am I just crying because my sneaky ninja coworkers are cutting onions again? Is this how Anton Ego felt when he took his first bite of that ratatouille? Well, in Whoville they say that the Grinch's small heart grew three sizes that day.

Rooster & Rice, located as part of the nice plaza at 303 2nd Street, is a small little restaurant that specializes in Khao Mun Gai which is also known as Hainanese Chicken. If you love Hainanese chicken, you'll for sure love the chicken here. If you're not sure if you love Hainanese chicken, then this might just be the place you fall in love with it.

I've passed by this place a couple times with an intention of trying it out, but I typically find a long line here around noon so I end up opting for something else. However, on this Friday afternoon, I noticed there wasn't a line so I rushed in and quickly ordered The Original to go. I was a bit skeptical of the chicken here once I found out it was boneless, since I love dark meat and find the meat around the bone to be the most juicy and flavorful. Also, when my meal came out to be $13 flat after tax without adding any extras such as veggies or egg, I thought to myself, "This better be good."

The Original comes with a bed of fragrant jasmine chicken rice, pieces of cucumber, some broth, and a soy based sauce with soybeans, ginger, garlic, and chili. They provide a good amount of meat which consists of both white breast meat and dark thigh meat. The meat is boneless, but has skin on it. The chicken turned out to be some of the most juicy chicken meat I've ever had. There was not a single piece of dry chicken to be found and each bite was a succulent artistic work that artists like Van Gogh and Ringo Starr could only dream of. It's just so wonderful to have such delicious boneless chicken meat since it isn't messy to eat and is also easy to eat which is great for a quick workday lunch. The rice is filled with the savory umami flavor from the chicken to make it the idea carb to complement the meat. The cucumber adds a contrast to all the umami flavor by adding a bit of sweetness to the meal\. The refreshing nature of it pairs very well with the chicken especially when the chicken is dipped in their habanero or thai sriracha sauce for a spicy kick. Their soy based sauce adds so many wonderful flavors with the chicken. The fragrance of the ginger with the saltiness of the soy sauce help to accentuate the natural flavors of the chicken rather than detract from it. If all this wasn't good enough, the chicken broth on the side provides an aspect of warmth to the meal, reminding me of homemade chicken soup that could heat up a home on a cold winter day and help heal the sick.

Needless to say, I'm a huge fan of Rooster & Chicken and if you're in the area looking for lunch, this restaurant is surely a solid choice!
author: Joshua M.

description:
Pricey!!! I enjoyed it, but I kept thinking if it's worth the $$$.....

I got the paleo (mixed chicken) bowl, but did half brown rice and half veggies - added an egg too! That came out to be ~$17. WOWZERS!!!


I ate it all at once too, so it's not like it can be split into two meals. I would recommend that you try it at least once.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Simple but filling! Got the #1, Flavors were on point, tastes really authentic. Might become one of my usual lunch spots!
author: Sammy P.

description:
Came here for lunch but wished they were open for dinner as well!!!

Although a simple chicken and rice dish, the flavors were there!!! The ginger soy sauce is to die for as many yelpers have suggested. There seems to always be a long line but it does go fast. 

I ordered the original and it was definitely not lacking in size. The portions are perfect if you are a heavy eater like myself!
author: Mai W.

description:
Thought that the khao mun gai here was a homey, comforting, and satisfying meal. 

I ordered The Original for myself. The chicken in the bowl was lean yet very tender and flavorful. My boyfriend ordered The Marina because he doesn't like when chicken is fatty or has skin, but I actually think that he would've been just as happy with The Original. The chicken in The Original (even the thigh) was just as lean, and I actually didn't get any skin in my bowl. That last part might be a big negative to some, but I didn't mind much. The broth was good too. Full of flavor, and not heavy or oily.

The jasmine rice was like the rice that's usually included in Hainan chicken dishes, in that it was very flavorful on its own. For that reason, don't dump the whole sauce container over the rice! The sauce is SUPER delicious, but if you put too much into the bowl, it can overpower the flavors of the chicken and the rice. Same goes for the optional Thai sriracha and the habanero sauce that they offer. SO good, but be careful how much you use because the bowl is far from bland even without them. 

Would this be 5 stars if this was cheaper? Definitely. In fact, I have no doubt that the same dish could be as little as half the price in Thai restaurants located elsewhere, like LA or Thailand itself. But let's be real: This is San Francisco. This is where many people don't think twice about dropping $15 for a simple salad. So Rooster & Rice isn't cheap, but I wouldn't say it's overpriced.

With that said, I really enjoyed the food here, and I'm happy that they opened this SoMa location.
author: Sara L.

description:
I'm told the food here is authentic, which I guess means a lot more to other folks. The chicken and rice dish (pretty much the only thing on the menu) is tasty enough, if a little bland on its own; you've got to pour on the included garlic/peanut sauce (or Sriracha) to get strong flavors. Once you do, it's pretty good. 

The portion sizes are solid, but you're still paying $12+ for chicken and rice and a little cup of broth. It doesn't quite feel like a great lunch value and I certainly don't enjoy waiting 20+ minutes in line to place my order and get the food. 

Beware the upsell! The first time I went there I blindly said "Yes" to every question they asked, and I walked away with a lunch that cost nearly $20. Serves me right for being such an agreeable person, I guess.
author: Alex L.

description:
The best khao mun gai in this part of the city. Their menu is small - chicken and rice, chicken and rice with veggies, chicken without rice with veggies, tofu and rice. That's it. It's all good. 
This spot is a local lunch place for the folks who work nearby. The lines are long between 12:15 and 1:15 - try and avoid those times.  Only a few seats inside - probably seats about 6-10 people max. Grab some chicken & rice then try to find a spot in the plaza on a warm day in SF (else, be prepared with a thick jacket).
author: Trang H.

description:
Having moved from Portland, OR I've been seeking for a replacement to fulfill my Khao Man Gai fix that I used to get from Nong's. 

Rooster and Rice does that and more. For a great price you can get one of the best comfort meals you can find in Asian cuisine. The R+R team does an impeccable job with everything. Making the sauce their own and making it so DELICIOUS. Fried chicken skins is a hit and is sharable for the 5 dollars it'll set you back. Totally worth it to mix it in your rice. 

I will definitely come again. My only nitpick is I'm not sure many of the goers have had experience with Khao Man Gai and some didn't touch the sauce at all or sip the soup after a spoonful of rice and chicken. I would excited reading into the dish to get the full experience! Because I'm so happy this place exists.
author: Tu D.

description:
I stumbled upon this place while trying to fit into my new ketogenic diet. I was tired of the norm sandwich, soup, and salads spots downtown so I decided to give this place a try. It didn't disappoint. Upon first entering, the aroma of chicken fills the air. The staff here is friendly and knowledgeable of the menu. They only have 4-5 things on the menu, however, they are all bomb af. 

I got The Paleo which is chicken and vegetables. The rice here is delicious as it's cooked with chicken stock (so delicious...). To accompany my dish, I used their house habenero sauce as well as their Thai chili sauce. Both I highly recommend. The meal is accompanied by a soup which compliments the muggy SF weather. All this cost me $14 (pretty normal for SF downtown lunch pricing). It didn't leave me in a food coma and it fits right in with my dietary needs. I highly recommend this place for anyone working downtown that wants to eat something healthy and delicious. Shout out Eugene (manager) and David (cashier). They're really the Steph Curry and Klay Thompson of this location.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Having had the best Chicken Rice of my life in Singapore (which is their national dish btw) - I was highly disappointed in the version being served here. I guess they've asterisked their version by labeling it as Thai.. but still.. where's the flavor of chicken in the rice? Where's the silky smooth chicken that's supposed to be star of the dish? 

This place probably just be renamed overcooked chicken on top of rice with some sliced cucumber. 

For those interested in trying some real Chicken Rice, go to Lime Tree on Clement Street.
author: Henry W.

description: $16 for flavorless chicken on top of broccoli with an egg that wasn't even poached on top but ended up at the bottom of the bowl. The mixed meat option has skin, not what expected. I guess you can get way with this in SOMA for lunch.
author: Inga W.

description: New favorite chicken comfort food place. Been here twice and I am a huge fan of the place already!! The sauce is delicious (I am a big ginger fan but even if you're not, you'll still like its sweetness). The chicken is nice and tender. You can sub brown rice for white at no extra charge. I have only gotten the original, but for me that's all I need! Friend got the paleo and it felt like there was a lot more chicken, but I could be wrong, as I easily finished mine while she took a while to eat. The broth soup it comes with is 10/10. It warms me from the inside out. I'm willing to pay the money for this place, which must mean it's GOOD. Will come again!
author: Serena W.

description: My girlfriend told me about this location.  This is my second time and now I know how to order.  I had the Original and the Marina.  Marina has brown rice and no skin on the chicken .  The original has white rice and skin on some pieces of the chicken.  I always call in so I can stand in line versus ordering there.  I love their broth as there is no MSG in it.  I wish there were more veggies with the meal.  Thank is why I am giving a 4 star.
author: Stephanie C.

description: this place is really good. Their garlic sauce goes well with the chicken and the chicken soup is nice and full of chicken fat flavor. Would return
author: Kay C.

description:
Finally, a decent place to get khao mun gai in SF! Kao mun gai, or the Thai verson ofHainan chicken rice, is one of the most popular street food in Singapore, and despite its extremely simple premise, is super flavorful. The secret is the super flavorful rice, flavored with chicken broth, chicken fat, oil, and whatever sauce you include, such as garlic. 

Rooster & Rice gives khao mun gai an SF flair, with an option to make it "Marina healthy" with skinless chicken breast and brown rice, or Paleo, chicken & veggie. I like the healthy customization, but if you want the true khao mun gai experience, you should try the Original option, with the poached/boiled chicken and the oh-so-delicious chicken fat rice. All orders also come with a ginger/garlic/spicy/sweet/soy sauce and a side of chicken broth, which you can drizzle on the chicken and rice to add more flavor. 

It's a tad expensive, especially for what is essentially street food in Asia, but it's definitely one of the best I've had outside of Singapore. The Marina location is bigger, while the SOMA location seems to be mostly a grab and go place.
author: Kate M.

description:
OMG OMG OMG, I almost fell out of my seat when I realized Rooster & Rice had opened up downstairs in my office building. Not only is it 100x better than its predecessor (Urban Picnic, RIP), I was excited since I had been wanting to try the original location for ages (except for the fact that it's in the Marina and I don't do the Marina).

For lunch, my date and I both got The Original; I asked for all dark meat juicy chicken. It was a cold day and the soup was a pleasant surprise. The chicken itself was tasty and the soy sauce based sauce was amazing! The rice was fantastic as well and had a good amount of chicken flavor.

The food is cooked authentically; only the price is not cheap. This is a great addition to the SOMA food scene and a wonderful complement to DragonEats nearby.
author: Yi Z.

description:
I am still a tad salty that I paid $13 for a bowl of Hainan style Chicken & Rice, but I guess it's all because SF pays their workers a higher minimum wage so I have no grounds to hate. 

This place caters to the lunch rush, there is not a lot of seating but there is plenty outside in the courtyard.

Nonetheless, the all of the bowls given a sizable amount of food! Very pleased with the portion. The standard bowl comes with a few cucumbers, soup, tons of rice, chicken boob & thigh, and soy sauce. 

Definitely a great option to break the usual sad salad routine in SoMa or for a quick, chill meal. It's gringo Hainan chicken for sure, but good in its own right.
author: Susan L.

description: Great, tasty filling lunch and cheap for San Francisco. The chicken is delicious every time and I love the broth.
author: Maggie S.

description: The food was pretty good. I'd say it is too bland if you don't add any sauces; but if you add too much, it can be overpowering. Considering the meal is just chicken and rice, I think it is a little overpriced at around $10- $12.
author: Wyatt S.

description: Went to grab a quick to go meal for lunch and was in and out within 10 minutes. I ordered the original: a very simple meal, basically just rice and chicken with a few cucumbers inside the box yet the sauce they provided definitely takes the meal to a new level. I like spicy food so I also added Habanero sauce to really get the flavor kicking. Everything came together much better than I expected especially after looking at the pictures of the meals which are rather basic. My only knock would be that it's a little more expensive than I expected, but I will definitely be going back.
author: LeVar H.

description: This place serves a Thai version of Hainanese chicken rice. It's delicious and addictive. The rice is subtly spiced with ginger and soy, the organic chicken is poached perfectly and they have a dipping sauce with chilis and ginger and soy with beans in it that is also so good. The long lines tell you how tasty it is. You can also get a fresh coconut to drink. It's pretty awesome.
author: Bunny C.

description: Straightforward, no-frills chicken and rice, delicious in its simplicity and high-quality ingredients. I got the Original, but there isn't much else choice on the menu (a good thing).
author: Josh L.

description:
The chicken is nice and moist and goes well with rice and the sauce they give you. The portion size is okay, like it won't leave you starving but still not the amount you'd expect from a $13-14 meal. I really like the sauce on the side, even though I'm usually repulsed by ginger because ginger tastes likes soap to me. I mean, it still does, so the sauce tastes like really good thai soap, if that makes sense. They also have a paleo option which is super cool since eating out on a low carb diet can be v difficult.

The best part about this place is the broth. Like oooommmmmmgggggg. I could just drink this shit all day. It's so flavorful and oily and goes so well with the chicken.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Busy during lunchtime with nearby yuppies but a good healthy/hearty alternative if you're not feeling a sandwich or salad. 

I got the original which comes with their jasmine rice, chicken, some cucumbers and a side of broth for $12. It's a bit pricey but the size is decent. Just wish they had more included options instead of a la carte items like $2 for egg lol. But all in all, everything tasted clean and the chicken was moist.

Not much table seating but plenty outside!
author: Amanda K.

description:
Pretty decent meal for a reasonable price.  The food's fairly plain and simple, which I think is a good thing!  Just as the name implies, it's basically just chicken and rice, but you can add some toppings like an egg if you want.  The original's pretty good and filling, and the side order of fried chicken skin is delicious!  

My favorite part is probably how simple the whole thing is, definitely a nice and easy lunch outing during work.
author: Keith C.

description:
Not gonna lie, I didn't have high expectations for this place but I was wrong! The chicken here is super high quality and flavored perfectly. I get the Paleo because I want veggies without having to pay for a side and they give you a tin of brown rice anyways. 

If you've never been, it's basically like Chinese Hainan chicken. It comes with chicken, rice, sauce, and a small soup. It's a bit expensive for what it is but on par for SF prices.
author: Ming Y.

description:
GENERAL: Back home in Indonesia I call this Hainan chicken. Famous in Singapore too. In general, you can still find these in the area, but to have it solely as a restaurant itself is amazing. This is a good to go food during lunch and good to eat in as well. Just come a little early around 11am, you'll be fine. 

FOOD: The big plus for me is when you can order solely breast chicken, in which not a lot of places do that. The sauce is... interesting in a sense that it has whole beans in it (i guess i'm not used to that) but the taste is spot on. Wondering about the soup? Drink it from the bowl or pour it over the rice.

TIP: Come at 11am if you wanna avoid the line. After 12pm you can get fried chicken skin by the bag for $5. Fresh coconut is amazing. You can also get any meat of your choosing - mine is breast meat.

IMPROVEMENTS: Maybe a different chili sauce because I've definitely had a better chili sauce that pairs really well with this cuisine.
author: Kevin L.

description: Everyone at work raved about this place so my expectations were too high. I find their food to be very plain... it's just plain chickens and rice but you add a sauce that adds flavor. I only gave this place 3 stars instead of 4 because I waited 35 min for my food. I noticed everyone else was only waiting about 10 min and it turns out their printer broke and they didn't get my order even though I paid and stood their waiting. I was super disappointed. The workers were very nice but the super long wait coupled with the plain chicken was very mediocre. If it wasn't for the wait and mess up on my order I would give it 4 stars.
author: Olivia C.

description:
Some of the most succulent chicken and tasty rice that I've ever had (at that price range). The sauces that come with it (both the ginger/sesame and the spicy one) make the meal complete. Some reviews are criticizing the lack of seasoning on the chicken. I think that you're supposed to combine the heavily seasoned rice and sauce in every bite.

Service was fast and friendly. The restaurant was clean.
author: Charles C.

description:
Great addition to this east SoMa area with a general lack of Asian food options. The shop was not super spacious but had a few tables and could get very busy during weekday lunch hours. 

Simple menu with just four options, one vegetarian and three with chicken. Five of us got all different chicken options. "Paleo" option could be confusing - no rice and instead more veggies. I wanted to bring it up because their rice was the highlight of the meal for me! Chicken flavor was noticeable in the rice along with garlic and ginger, very tasty and just like in the classic Singapore style Hainan chicken. I got extra veggies (steamed broccoli), though the original portion was already more than enough for me. It also came with soup (tasty warm broth), perfect for a chilly day :)

A bit on the pricey side ($12+ for chicken options) that probably made me not go every time I ate out in the area, but certainly a place I'd crave once in a while.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
This reminded me a little of Hainanese Chicken Rice, except with a side of chicken broth.  Pretty limited menu, so at least you know they specialize with their main dish.  It was worth trying, but it's not going to make it into my Top 20 favorite Thai dishes.

The Original:  Oddly, I liked everything about the dish except the actual chicken.  The rice was very rich and full of chicken flavor; I could probably eat mounds of this.  The chicken broth was more intense than typical chicken soup (maybe more fat content?) and did an excellent job at warming up the lukewarm chicken.  The soy-based sauce with ginger, garlic and chili added a ton of personality to the chicken and really was a treat if you dip the chicken in the broth first.  The cucumbers and cilantro help add a nice vegetal kick to cut through the richness of everything else.  The chicken though just wasn't my thing.  The limp boiled skin had such a weird slimy mouthfeel.  The chicken meat itself isn't that warm so it had the cooled off chicken taste.  And there were pieces of bone and cartilage in the mix.  In theory I'm not opposed to picking meat from the non-meat parts, but not in the middle of the workday when in nice business attire and surrounded by a bunch of professionals.  Pulling a piece of bone out of your mouth and putting it aside just seems so awkward.
author: Adam B.

description:
Flashbak to Thailand 
I remember that taste at the HuaHin
author: Dmitry B.

description:
Visited this place after looking for a place to eat for lunch. Seemed to be a new lunch spot providing new options for the workers in the area tucked into the plaza. Expanding from their Marina location, they made their way down to SOMA opening this place.

Upon walking into this place, it seems like a restaurant meant for a quick bite with takeout. It's very bright and very modern styled spot with a friendly atmosphere. In the back, the place is where the ordering happens and the rest of the magic.

I ended up ordering the Paleo. Wanted to go with more vegetables and meat option instead of the having the rice accompanying the meal. Took the recommendation of getting the egg on the side. After receiving it seems pretty well presented. Vegetables layered on the bottom with the steamed chicken layered on top and the poached egg on the side. Layering on top is the cilantro, sauces, and the soup finishing off the plate.

Starting off the soup. I will say this option was a superb compliment to the soup tasting like home. It had a bit of a sour taste, but the flavor from some vegetables that probably have been in the pot for a while. 

The chicken had a bit of a supple, moist flavor with which had a nice vinegar like taste from the sauce with some spice. With flavors of the egg meshing with the chicken, it provides a great fulfilling experience to the meal. 

Overall I would say this place is a great recommendation to get a pretty close traditional meal while being a tad experience. Due to the price, I will give it a 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Frank O.

description:
I'd say this place is really a 3.5 rather than a 3.  

Food - a solid 4 stars.  The menu is limited to a few main entrees, and their focus means these options are very high quality.  The ingredients are top notch and well-sourced (organic chicken etc).  The food, at first glance, looks relatively plain, but the chicken is cooked to tender perfection and once you add the sauce, your whole experience becomes layered w salty, spicy, fresh flavor.

Ambiance - 3.5 stars.  It has a clean, bright, light interior.  Not a ton of seating and most of it is communal, which I'm not a huge fan of.  I understand why they do it though - it is a more efficient use of space.  The seating area isn't as cramped as many SOMA restaurants, but it's not exactly sprawling either.

Value/price - 2 stars.  I understand they are using really high quality ingredients, and those ingredients cost money.  However, w tax and tip and no extras, this lunch was over $17 to go.
